title: Day 20 - Test, Test, and Test Again
mainPromise: You will design and run small tests on your message and offer so improvements are based on evidence, not guesswork.

teachings.title: Tests need a single variable
teachings.content:
When results are unclear, people change everything at once: headline, price, page, platform, and script. That makes it impossible to learn what actually caused the change.

A good test changes one thing at a time. For example: opener line, call to action, price framing, or a single bullet list. Keep everything else constant for the test window.

You are not doing scientific perfection. You are doing practical learning. Small tests produce fast feedback and protect your motivation.
teachings.soWhat: If you cannot isolate one variable, your next decision will be based on stories instead of data.

teachings.title: Prepare test variants that stay honest
teachings.content:
Testing is not tricking people. It is presenting the same truthful offer in different phrasing. Your variants should not promise different outcomes. They should emphasize different angles: speed, clarity, reduced frustration, or a specific pain.

For a small online service, the most testable elements are: the first sentence, the headline, the CTA, and the top bullet list. Small edits can make a big difference.

Today you will write two variants for each of your three tests.
teachings.soWhat: If you do not prepare clean variants, your tests will be inconsistent and hard to compare.

teachings.title: Run the smallest test now
teachings.content:
A test that stays in your notebook is not a test. You need to run at least one small test today, even if it is only a handful of messages.

Early tests often use outreach because it is fast: send a few messages with Variant A, a few with Variant B, then compare replies. You can also test page changes by swapping headline and seeing which gets more link clicks.

You will run one micro-test and record outcomes in your launch log.
teachings.soWhat: If you do not run a test, you cannot improve, and your launch stays stuck.

doBlocks.title: Define three micro-tests
steps: Choose three test variables (message, page, or offer).
Write a hypothesis and success metric for each.
Define a small sample size and a time window.

items.label: Chose three test variables, one per test
items.evidencePrompt: List three variables you will test (one per test).

items.label: Wrote a hypothesis for each test
items.evidencePrompt: Write three hypotheses in the form: If we change X, then Y.

items.label: Defined a success metric for each
items.evidencePrompt: For each test, write a metric and a numeric threshold (for example, 3 replies out of 10).

items.label: Defined sample size and time window for each test
items.evidencePrompt: For each test, write sample size and time window.

doBlocks.example: Test 1 variable: Opener line. Hypothesis: If opener names the weekly pain, replies increase. Metric: 3 replies out of 10 messages. Window: 24 hours.

doBlocks.title: Create your test variants
steps: Write Variant A and Variant B for each test.
Keep both variants short and comparable.
Add a version tag so you can log results cleanly.

items.label: Wrote A and B variants for Test 1
items.evidencePrompt: Paste the two labeled variants for Test 1 (A and B).

items.label: Wrote A and B variants for Test 2
items.evidencePrompt: Paste the two labeled variants for Test 2 (A and B).

items.label: Wrote A and B variants for Test 3
items.evidencePrompt: Paste the two labeled variants for Test 3 (A and B).

items.label: Added version tags for all six variants
items.evidencePrompt: List six version tags (for example, T1A, T1B, T2A, T2B, T3A, T3B) and map them to text.

doBlocks.example: T1A opener: Are you losing time each week to the same admin tasks? T1B opener: Do you want a workflow set up so you stop rebuilding your process every Monday?

doBlocks.title: Run one test and log results
steps: Choose one test to run today.
Send a small batch using both variants (for example, 4 and 4).
Log outcomes and decide what to keep tomorrow.

items.label: Selected the test you will run today
items.evidencePrompt: Write the test ID you ran today and one line on why it matters.

items.label: Sent Variant A to at least 4 targets and Variant B to at least 4 targets
items.evidencePrompt: Paste both variant texts and record counts and platform used.

items.label: Logged replies, link clicks, or next-step requests
items.evidencePrompt: Paste a small results table showing variant, count sent, and outcomes.

items.label: Wrote a keep/change decision for tomorrow
items.evidencePrompt: Write one decision line: keep/change and why, based on outcomes.

doBlocks.example: Result: T1A got 2 replies, T1B got 0 replies. Decision: Keep T1A and rewrite T1B opener angle to be more specific.

outputs: Three micro-test plans with hypotheses and metrics
Six labeled variants with version tags
One completed test run with logged outcomes
wrap.tomorrowPreview: Tomorrow you will simplify aggressively by removing optional parts that slow selling or confuse buyers, so your offer becomes easier to say yes to.
